G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u202f19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the amount in controversy is less than $25,000 and the property that is the subject of this action is located within this judicial district.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u202f3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the amount in controversy is less than $25,000 and the property that is the subject of this action is located within this judicial district.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(c).proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(c) and G.L. c. 223, §§ 1–2, as the cause of action arose in Springfield.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7\u202f1\u20132.proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(c) and G.L. c. 223, §§ 1–2, as the cause of action arose in Springfield.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7\u202f8A.proposition: The condition of the Premises violates Massachusetts law requiring landlords to maintain residential dwellings in habitable condition.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts recognizes both an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential lease and a statutory remedy for its violation.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes an implied covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies. It discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 as the "quiet enjoyment" statute providing a statutory cause of action and remedy, and it simultaneously treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as an implied condition of residential leases, analyzing landlord liability for interference. Thus, it supports that Massachusetts recognizes both an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential lease and a statutory remedy for its violation.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs argue that the judge erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the defendant on their claim that the defendant violated G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), the so-called ‘quiet enjoyment’ statute. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 94 (1982)... General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts recognizes both an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential lease and a statutory remedy for its violation.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that every tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, referencing prior Massachusetts cases, and then construes G.L. c. 186, §14 as providing a statutory cause of action, including damages and attorneys’ fees, for interference with quiet enjoyment of residential premises. The court applies §14 directly to the tenant’s claim and upholds an attorneys’ fee award under that statute, confirming both the implied covenant and the existence of a statutory remedy for its violation in residential leases.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute…. Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages… and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee….”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: A substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the leased premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent intentional misconduct.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly holds that some degree of landlord fault—at least negligence with notice or reason to know—is required for liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment and rejects strict liability. While the case recognizes that substantial interferences (e.g., unrepaired defects) can breach quiet enjoyment, it ties that breach to negligent or more culpable conduct, not to substantial interference alone "absent intentional misconduct." Thus the proposition overstates the standard by omitting the required negligence component.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: A substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the leased premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent intentional misconduct.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects any requirement of intent for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, stating that the landlord’s conduct, not his intentions, is controlling. It holds that a substantial deprivation of quiet enjoyment caused as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done constitutes a breach and constructive eviction, even though the landlords “did not intend to create the conditions.”
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Berman v. Sitrin, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 240.raw_text: Berman v. Sitrin, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 240 (2006)
Berman v. Sitrin, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 240.proposition: Defendant’s failure to restore electricity constitutes a “serious interference” with Plaintiff’s right to a habitable and functional dwelling.
Berman v. Sitrin, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 240.support_reasoning: The opinion is about waiver of lease conditions relating to an option to purchase and the effect of late rent payments; it does not address conditions of habitability, utility service, or what constitutes a ‘serious interference’ with a residential tenant’s right to a habitable or functional dwelling. The premises here are commercial (auto sales/repair), and the court never discusses electricity shutoff or habitability standards. Thus the case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Berman v. Sitrin, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 240.relevant_excerpt: “The parties entered into a lease commencing October 1, 1999, and ending December 31, 2004, for premises to be used for the sale and repair of motor vehicles. For purposes of this opinion the two relevant provisions of the lease are clause 18(a) and clause 21(B) which read as follows: ‘18. DEFAULT AND BANKRUPTCY…’ … ‘21. OTHER PROVISIONS. (B) OPTION TO PURCHASE. Provided that LESSEE has complied with all provisions of this lease, LESSEE shall have an option to purchase…’”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Electrical service is an essential facility required for habitability.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence/dissent that discusses an implied warranty of habitability in general and argues that the landlord’s obligation should at least encompass compliance with the State Sanitary Code. However, in this excerpt the opinion does not specifically identify electrical service as an ‘essential facility’ or expressly say that electricity is required for habitability. While the broader case recognizes a warranty tied to code-based minimum standards, this section does not clearly establish the specific proposition about electrical service, so using it as direct authority for that narrow point would be overstating it.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall ... let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit, for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein, which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions.”

Fiorillo v. Winiker, 356 Mass. 96 (1969).proposition: A landlord may not delay necessary repairs so as to effectively deprive a tenant of use of a portion of the dwelling.
Fiorillo v. Winiker, 356 Mass. 96 (1969).support_reasoning: The opinion in Fiorillo v. Winiker is a criminal case about suppression of evidence obtained by foreign (Canadian) police and the admissibility of statements under Miranda; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, repairs, or deprivation of use of a dwelling. Nothing in the holding or reasoning discusses a landlord’s duty to make timely repairs or restrictions on delaying such repairs. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about landlords and necessary repairs.
Fiorillo v. Winiker, 356 Mass. 96 (1969).relevant_excerpt: We hold that statements voluntarily made to foreign police, like such statements made to private citizens in this country (Commonwealth v. White, 353 Mass. 409, 414-417), are admissible even if the Miranda warnings were not given. We are of opinion that the statements under consideration were voluntary.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The Defendant’s conduct constitutes a constructive interruption of use and enjoyment prohibited by the statute.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses “constructive interruption of use and enjoyment” as a statutory concept, nor does it analyze landlord conduct under a statute phrased in those terms. The case addresses warranty of habitability, the State Sanitary Code heat-and-hot-water requirements, security deposit violations, rent control overcharges, and G.L. c. 93A, but not a statutory prohibition on constructive interruption of use and enjoyment. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.

…

Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Defendant’s prolonged delay after notice constitutes a knowing and willful interference within the meaning of § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss when conduct is ‘knowing or wilful’ for purposes of multiple damages under G.L. c. 93A, but it expressly upholds the trial judge’s conclusion that the landlord’s conduct—though prolonged and negligent—was not knowing or wilful. The court emphasizes that repeated but ineffectual repair efforts can characterize the conduct as negligent rather than knowing or wilful, and it does not state that mere prolonged delay after notice, by itself, constitutes knowing and wilful interference under § 14 (or for c. 93A multiple damages). Thus the case does not support the claimed proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: "Under G. L. c. 93A, § 9 (3) (1992 ed.), a plaintiff prevailing on a c. 93A claim may be awarded 'up to three but not less than two times [the actual damages] if the court finds that the use or employment of the act or practice was a willful or knowing violation ... or that the refusal to grant relief upon demand was made in bad faith.' Here, the judge found that Cruz Management made repeated attempts to repair the defects in the apartment... It was open to the judge to conclude that conditions in the leased premises were attributable to negligent attempts at repair, and not to a knowing or wilful disregard of the conditions in the apartment."}

Guzman v. Pring-Wilson, 81 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Guzman v. Pring-Wilson, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 430 (2012)
Guzman v. Pring-Wilson, 81 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s prolonged delay after notice constitutes a knowing and willful interference within the meaning of § 14.
Guzman v. Pring-Wilson, 81 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns negligence versus intentional tort in a wrongful death/self-defense context and does not interpret or apply any § 14, nor does it discuss knowing and willful interference or delay after notice. The proposition about a defendant’s prolonged delay constituting knowing and willful interference within the meaning of § 14 is unrelated to the issues actually decided. Therefore, this case cannot be cited as authority for that specific statutory proposition.
Guzman v. Pring-Wilson, 81 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: On appeal, Pring-Wilson’s sole claim is that, although the judge’s factual findings are sound, those facts require an ultimate finding that he acted intentionally, not that he was negligent... Moreover, even though Pring-Wilson’s display of the knife was an intentional act, that act did not preclude the judge’s finding of negligence... Where negligence is at issue, though, the focus is on the consequences.
